source.name: City and County of Denver - Recycle, Compost, Trash
source.notes: Based on official Denver recycling, composting, and trash guidelines. Denver uses purple (recycling), green (compost), and black (trash) carts. Recycling is bi-weekly as of January 2025.

materials.name: Plastic bottles
instructions: Rinse lightly
Keep lids ON (Denver accepts lids attached to bottles)
Place in purple recycling cart
notes: Purple cart recycling is collected bi-weekly (changed from weekly in January 2025)
Check Denver Trash and Recycling App for your collection day
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with liquid still in them
Don't crush — keep 3-dimensional for sorting machinery

materials.name: Rigid plastic containers
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in purple recycling cart
notes: Rigid plastics only — no flexible or film plastics
Use the Be Cart Smart tool on denvergov.org if unsure
commonMistakes: No styrofoam or foam containers
No black plastic trays — sorting machines can't detect them

materials.name: Aluminum cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Do NOT crush — keep cans 3-dimensional
Place in purple recycling cart
notes: Denver specifically asks you NOT to crush aluminum cans; 3D shape helps sorting machinery identify them correctly
Purple cart is collected bi-weekly
commonMistakes: Do NOT crush or flatten aluminum cans
Don't include cans with food residue

materials.name: Steel / tin cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Labels can stay on
Place in purple recycling cart
notes: A magnet will stick to steel cans but not aluminum
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food still in them

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
instructions: Empty and rinse
Remove lids (metal lids can be recycled separately)
Place in purple recycling cart
notes: Denver accepts glass curbside in the purple cart — unlike some cities that require drop-off
All colors of glass accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass — wrap and place in black trash cart
Don't include ceramics, mirrors, or window glass

materials.name: Cardboard
instructions: Flatten all boxes to 2ft × 2ft pieces or smaller
Remove packing materials (bubble wrap, styrofoam, air pillows)
Place INSIDE the purple recycling cart — not beside it
notes: Denver requires cardboard to be flattened to max 2ft × 2ft pieces so it fits inside the cart
Bi-weekly purple cart collection
commonMistakes: Don't leave boxes unflattened
Don't place cardboard outside the cart — it must fit inside
Don't include cardboard soaked with grease (that goes in black cart)

materials.name: Paperboard / thin cardboard
instructions: Flatten
Remove plastic liners or windows if possible
Place in purple recycling cart
notes: Thin cardboard boxes (like cereal and shoe boxes) are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't forget to remove plastic liner bags
Don't include if heavily soiled with food

materials.name: Newspapers
instructions: Place in purple recycling cart
No need to bundle or tie
notes: Inserts and ads can stay with the newspaper
commonMistakes: Don't bag newspapers in plastic bags

materials.name: Magazines and catalogs
instructions: Place in purple recycling cart
notes: Glossy paper and staples are fine
commonMistakes: Don't remove staples — they're filtered during processing

materials.name: Mail and office paper
instructions: Place in purple recycling cart
Window envelopes are okay — no need to remove the plastic window
notes: Shredded paper: place in a paper bag, staple shut, then put in purple cart
commonMistakes: Don't bag paper in plastic bags
Don't include paper towels or tissues

materials.name: Milk / juice / broth cartons
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap if it has one
Place in purple recycling cart
notes: Cartons are accepted in Denver's purple cart recycling
commonMistakes: Don't flatten — keep 3-dimensional for sorting

materials.name: Pizza box (clean)
instructions: If the pizza box is clean or has minimal grease, place in purple recycling cart
Tear off and recycle the clean lid; trash the greasy bottom
notes: Denver accepts clean pizza boxes in recycling — a common question answered on Be Cart Smart
commonMistakes: Greasy pizza boxes should NOT go in the purple cart
Do NOT put pizza boxes in the green compost cart — Denver composting does not accept paper products

materials.name: Pizza box (greasy)
instructions: Greasy/soiled pizza boxes go in the black trash cart
If only the bottom is greasy, tear off the clean top for recycling
notes: Unlike many cities, Denver's composting program does NOT accept paper products, so greasy pizza boxes cannot be composted
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy pizza boxes in the purple recycling cart
Don't put in the green compost cart — Denver composting does not take paper

materials.name: Aerosol cans
instructions: Must be completely empty
Do not puncture or crush
Place in purple recycling cart
notes: Non-empty aerosols are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if still pressurized
Don't puncture cans

materials.name: Aluminum foil
instructions: Clean off all food residue
Ball up into a fist-sized ball
Place in purple recycling cart
notes: Clean foil is recyclable; heavily soiled foil goes in black cart
commonMistakes: Don't recycle foil with baked-on food
Don't include foil-lined chip bags (those are trash)

materials.name: Aluminum trays and pie pans
instructions: Rinse clean
Place in purple recycling cart
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include heavily soiled trays

materials.name: Food waste (all types)
instructions: Place ALL food scraps in the green compost cart — including meat, bones, dairy, and cooked food
No bag needed; place food directly in the cart or use a small CMA-certified compostable bag (max 3 gallons)
notes: Denver's green cart accepts all food waste: fruits, vegetables, meat, bones, fish, dairy, bread, grains, everything
Green cart is collected weekly
Denver composting is rolling out in phases across districts
commonMistakes: Don't put food in the black trash cart if you have green cart service
Don't use regular plastic bags — only CMA-certified compostable bags
Do NOT put paper products in the green cart — Denver composting does not accept paper

materials.name: Fruit and fruit scraps
instructions: Place in green compost cart
All fruit and fruit scraps accepted
notes: Green cart collected weekly
commonMistakes: Don't put fruit in the black trash cart — compost it
Don't put in a regular plastic bag

materials.name: Vegetables and vegetable scraps
instructions: Place in green compost cart
notes: All vegetables accepted in Denver composting
commonMistakes: Don't put in the black trash cart

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Place in green compost cart — Denver accepts ALL meat and bones
Includes raw and cooked meat, fish, poultry, and bones
notes: Denver's industrial composting facility handles meat and bones safely
Green cart collected weekly
commonMistakes: Don't put meat in the black trash cart if you have green cart service
Don't worry about raw vs cooked — both accepted

materials.name: Dairy products
instructions: Place dairy products in green compost cart — Denver accepts all dairy
Pour expired milk down drain; compost the residue
notes: Rinse and recycle the container separately in the purple cart
commonMistakes: Don't put dairy in the black trash cart — compost it

materials.name: Bread and grains
instructions: Place in green compost cart
notes: All grain products accepted in composting
commonMistakes: Don't put in the black trash cart if you have green cart service

materials.name: Coffee grounds / tea bags
instructions: Coffee grounds: place directly in green compost cart
Paper coffee filters: place in black trash cart (Denver composting does not accept paper products)
Paper tea bags: black trash cart; loose tea leaves: green cart
notes: Important: Denver's composting does NOT accept paper products — this is unusual compared to most cities
Only the food portion goes in the green cart
commonMistakes: Don't put paper coffee filters in the green cart — they are paper products
Check if tea bags are plastic mesh (trash) or paper (also trash in Denver)

materials.name: Eggs / eggshells
instructions: Crush eggshells and place in green compost cart
notes: Eggshells add calcium to compost
commonMistakes: Crush for faster breakdown

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Place in green compost cart
Branches: must be under 4 feet long and under 4 inches in diameter
Green cart collected weekly year-round
notes: Large branches exceeding 4ft/4in can be taken to a Denver drop-off event
Denver's green cart accepts both food waste and yard waste together
commonMistakes: Don't put branches over 4ft long or 4in diameter in the green cart
Don't bag yard waste in plastic bags

materials.name: Compostable bags (CMA-certified)
instructions: Only CMA (Compost Manufacturers Alliance) certified compostable bags are accepted
Must be 3 gallons or smaller
Use to line a kitchen pail and carry food scraps to the green cart
notes: Look for the CMA logo — not all bags labeled 'compostable' are CMA-certified
Available at grocery stores and hardware stores
commonMistakes: Don't use regular plastic bags in the green cart
Don't use bags labeled 'biodegradable' — must be CMA-certified
Bags over 3 gallons are NOT accepted

materials.name: Plastic bags
instructions: Do NOT put in purple recycling cart
Take clean dry bags to King Soopers or Safeway store drop-off bins
Otherwise place in black trash cart
notes: Plastic bags are a top contaminant in Denver recycling — they tangle in sorting machinery
Classified as 'tanglers' by Denver's recycling program
commonMistakes: Never bag recyclables in plastic bags and put in the purple cart
Don't put any film plastic in the purple cart

materials.name: Styrofoam / polystyrene
instructions: Place in black trash cart
Not accepted in Denver's recycling or composting programs
notes: Styrofoam cannot be processed by Denver's recycling facility
commonMistakes: Don't put styrofoam in the purple recycling cart
Don't put in the green compost cart

materials.name: Tanglers (hoses, cords, chains)
instructions: Place in black trash cart
Do NOT put in purple recycling cart — these are 'tanglers'
notes: Denver specifically warns against tanglers: hoses, cords, chains, string lights, rope. They wrap around recycling machinery and cause shutdowns
Contact denvercartsmart@denvergov.org for special disposal questions
commonMistakes: Never put hoses, cords, chains, or rope in the purple recycling cart

materials.name: Electronics / E-waste
instructions: Do NOT put in any curbside cart
Take to a Denver Sustainability drop-off event
Or take to a permanent electronics recycling facility
Delete personal data before disposal
notes: Denver hosts periodic sustainability drop-off events for electronics
Check the Denver Trash and Recycling App for upcoming events
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in the black trash cart or purple recycling cart
Don't forget to wipe personal data

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Do NOT put in any curbside cart
Take to a Denver Sustainability drop-off event or permanent facility
Tape terminals of lithium and 9V batteries before transport
notes: Batteries can cause fires in garbage trucks and recycling facilities
Check Denver Trash and Recycling App for drop-off events
commonMistakes: Don't throw batteries in the black trash cart
Don't put in the purple recycling cart

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to a Denver Sustainability drop-off event
Latex paint: can also dry out with kitty litter, then place in black trash cart with lid off
Oil-based paint: must go to hazardous waste event
notes: Denver hosts regular sustainability events that accept paint
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down the drain
Don't put liquid paint in the black trash cart

materials.name: Motor oil
instructions: Take to a Denver sustainability drop-off event
AutoZone and O'Reilly in Denver also accept used oil
notes: Most auto parts stores accept oil for free
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains or into storm sewers

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Take to a Denver police department drug take-back location
Walgreens and King Soopers pharmacies in Denver may have take-back kiosks
If no drop-off available: mix with coffee grounds or kitty litter, seal in container, trash
notes: Never flush medications — they contaminate Denver's water supply
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications
Don't put in recycling

materials.name: CFL and fluorescent bulbs
instructions: Take to a Denver sustainability drop-off event
Home Depot and Lowe's in Denver also accept CFL bulbs
Handle carefully — contains mercury
notes: Do not break fluorescent bulbs; mercury vapor is hazardous
commonMistakes: Don't put in the black trash cart
Don't break them

materials.name: LED and incandescent bulbs
instructions: Wrap and place in black trash cart
LED bulbs can also be taken to e-waste recycling
notes: Incandescent and halogen bulbs are not hazardous but not recyclable curbside
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with CFL bulbs which are hazardous

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate to Goodwill, ARC Thrift Stores, or Denver Rescue Mission
Textile recycling bins located throughout Denver
Worn-out textiles still accepted at textile bins
notes: ARC Thrift Stores are a Denver-area staple for clothing donation
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing in any curbside cart

materials.name: Cooking oil / grease
instructions: Collect in a sealed container
Take to a Denver sustainability drop-off event
Small amounts can be absorbed with paper towels and placed in black trash cart
notes: Never pour oil down the drain — it clogs Denver's sewer system
commonMistakes: Don't pour down sink or storm drains

materials.name: Propane tanks
instructions: Take to a Denver sustainability drop-off event
Never put in any curbside cart
notes: Pressurized containers are fire and explosion risks in garbage trucks
commonMistakes: Never puncture
Never put in trash, recycling, or compost

materials.name: Needles / sharps
instructions: Place in an FDA-cleared sharps container or heavy plastic container (like a laundry detergent bottle)
Label container 'SHARPS'
Take to a Denver sustainability drop-off event or pharmacy take-back
notes: Never place loose sharps in any cart
commonMistakes: Never put in recycling, compost, or loose in trash

materials.name: Candy wrapper
instructions: Place in black trash cart
Metallized plastic film — not recyclable
notes: Candy wrappers look metallic but are not aluminum; they are multi-layer film
commonMistakes: Don't put in the purple recycling cart
Don't put in the green compost cart

materials.name: Chip bag / snack bag
instructions: Place in black trash cart
Metallized plastic — not recyclable in Denver
notes: The shiny interior is aluminum bonded to plastic film; not separable
commonMistakes: Don't put in the purple recycling cart

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Lined paper cups: black trash cart
Plastic lids: purple recycling cart
Paper sleeve/collar: purple recycling cart
notes: The plastic or wax lining prevents paper cup recycling
Denver composting does not accept paper products, so these cannot be composted
commonMistakes: Don't put lined cups in the purple recycling cart
Don't put in the green compost cart

materials.name: Diapers
instructions: Bag and place in black trash cart
notes: Not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green compost cart
Don't put in the purple recycling cart

materials.name: Receipts
instructions: Place in black trash cart
Thermal paper contains BPA — cannot be recycled or composted
notes: Thermal receipts contaminate paper recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the purple recycling cart
Don't put in the green compost cart

materials.name: Pet waste
instructions: Bag and place in black trash cart
Do NOT compost pet waste
notes: Pet waste contains harmful bacteria not handled by Denver's composting
commonMistakes: Never put in the green compost cart
Don't flush cat litter

materials.name: Food-soiled paper
instructions: Place in black trash cart
Denver's composting program does NOT accept paper products
notes: This is unusual: most cities allow food-soiled paper in composting, but Denver does not
Check Be Cart Smart on denvergov.org if unsure
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green compost cart — Denver composting does not accept paper
Don't put in the purple recycling cart — soiled paper contaminates recycling

materials.name: Books
instructions: Donate if in good condition — Denver Public Library, ARC Thrift Stores, Goodwill
If damaged, place paper pages in purple recycling cart
Remove hardcovers with glossy laminate (trash those)
notes: Donating is always preferable to recycling
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in the black trash cart

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place in a paper bag
Staple or tape the bag shut
Place the sealed bag in the purple recycling cart
notes: Loose shredded paper is too small for sorting machinery — must be bagged in paper
commonMistakes: Don't put loose shredded paper in the purple cart
Don't use a plastic bag

materials.name: Fast food wrapper
instructions: Food-soiled fast food wrappers: black trash cart
Clean paper wrappers: purple recycling cart if unlined
notes: Denver composting does not accept paper products, so greasy wrappers go to trash
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy wrappers in the purple recycling cart
Don't put in the green compost cart

materials.name: Bubble wrap / packing materials
instructions: Place in black trash cart
Or drop off plastic film at King Soopers/Safeway store collection bins
notes: Plastic film jams Denver's recycling machinery — it's a tangler
commonMistakes: Don't put in the purple recycling cart

materials.name: Wax paper / parchment paper
instructions: Place in black trash cart
Not recyclable due to wax/silicone coating
Denver composting does not accept paper products
notes: Cannot be recycled or composted in Denver
commonMistakes: Don't put in the purple recycling cart
Don't put in the green compost cart

materials.name: Mirrors
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper or cloth
Place in black trash cart
Label as BROKEN GLASS if applicable
notes: Metallic coating prevents glass recycling
commonMistakes: Never put in the purple recycling cart with regular glass

materials.name: Ceramics / pottery
instructions: Place in black trash cart
Not accepted in glass or other recycling
notes: Ceramics contaminate glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the purple recycling cart
Don't mix with glass bottles

materials.name: Large / bulk items
instructions: Schedule an Extra Trash/Large Item pickup through Denver 311 or denvergov.org
Place at curb on your scheduled collection day
Or take to a Denver sustainability drop-off event
notes: Denver offers large item pickup — schedule through Denver 311 (720-913-1311)
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling a pickup

materials.name: Mattress
instructions: Schedule a large item pickup through Denver 311
Or take to a Denver sustainability drop-off event
notes: Denver offers large item pickup by appointment
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Appliances
instructions: Schedule large item pickup through Denver 311
Or take to a recycling/scrap facility
Remove doors from refrigerators for safety
notes: Appliances contain recyclable metals but cannot go in curbside carts
commonMistakes: Don't put in the black trash cart
Remove refrigerant from cooling appliances (requires professional)

materials.name: Chargers and cables
instructions: Take to a Denver sustainability drop-off event or Best Buy for recycling
Do NOT put in the purple recycling cart — these are tanglers
notes: Cables and cords wrap around recycling machinery and cause shutdowns
Denver classifies these as tanglers
commonMistakes: Never put cables, chargers, or cords in the purple recycling cart

materials.name: Smartphone / cell phone
instructions: Factory reset and wipe personal data first
Trade in at carrier stores or Apple/Samsung
Take to Best Buy or Denver sustainability drop-off event for free recycling
notes: Phones contain valuable recoverable materials
commonMistakes: Don't forget to wipe personal data
Don't put in the black trash cart — battery fire risk

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to a tire retailer or Denver sustainability drop-off event
Most tire shops accept old tires when you buy new ones
notes: Tires are banned from Colorado landfills
commonMistakes: Don't dump illegally
Don't put in any curbside cart

materials.name: Ink / toner cartridges
instructions: Return to Staples or Office Depot in Denver
Manufacturers often offer free mail-back programs
Best Buy also accepts cartridges
notes: Some stores give credit or rewards for returns
commonMistakes: Don't throw in the black trash cart

materials.name: Snacks and candy (the food itself)
instructions: The food portion: green compost cart
The wrapper: black trash cart
notes: Separate the food from the wrapper
commonMistakes: Don't put wrappers in the green cart

materials.name: Condiments and sauces
instructions: The sauce itself: green compost cart
The bottle/container: rinse and put in purple recycling cart
notes: Separate the container from the contents
commonMistakes: Don't recycle containers with sauce still in them

materials.name: Beverages / leftover drinks
instructions: Pour leftover liquid down drain or into green compost cart
Recycle the container in the purple cart (cans, plastic bottles, glass)
notes: Focus on recycling the container properly
commonMistakes: Don't recycle containers with liquid still in them
Empty containers first

materials.name: Toothbrush
instructions: Place in black trash cart
notes: Mixed plastic materials; not recyclable curbside
commonMistakes: Don't put in the purple recycling cart

materials.name: Makeup / cosmetics containers
instructions: Most cosmetics containers: black trash cart
Clean empty rigid plastic containers (#1, #2, #5) may go in purple cart
Nail polish: hazardous waste drop-off
notes: Small items often fall through sorting screens at recycling facilities
commonMistakes: Don't put nail polish in the black trash cart — it's hazardous

materials.name: Plastic straws and utensils
instructions: Place in black trash cart
Too small and lightweight for recycling machinery
notes: These fall through screens at recycling facilities
commonMistakes: Don't put in the purple recycling cart

materials.name: Hangers
instructions: Wire hangers: black trash cart (they're tanglers)
Plastic hangers: black trash cart
Or donate in good condition to dry cleaners or thrift stores
notes: Wire hangers are tanglers that jam recycling equipment
commonMistakes: Don't put in the purple recycling cart

materials.name: Wrapping paper
instructions: Metallic, glittery, or laminated wrapping paper: black trash cart
Plain paper wrapping (no coating): purple recycling cart
notes: Do the scrunch test: if it stays scrunched, it may be recyclable. If it springs back, it's metallic/laminated and goes in trash
commonMistakes: Don't put metallic or glittery wrapping paper in recycling
Ribbons and bows are trash

materials.name: Takeout foam containers
instructions: Place in black trash cart
Not recyclable or compostable in Denver
notes: Polystyrene foam (#6) is not accepted in any Denver program
commonMistakes: Don't put in the purple recycling cart
Don't put in the green compost cart

recycle: Plastic bottles with lids (keep 3D, don't crush)
compost: ALL food waste — fruit, vegetables, meat, bones, dairy, bread, grains
Coffee grounds and tea leaves (no paper filters)
Paper products of any kind (napkins, paper towels, paper plates, coffee filters)

tips: Denver uses 3 carts: PURPLE (recycling, bi-weekly), GREEN (compost, weekly), BLACK (trash, weekly)
Do NOT crush aluminum cans — keep them 3-dimensional so sorting machinery can identify them
Flatten cardboard to 2ft × 2ft pieces and place INSIDE the purple cart
Denver composting does NOT accept paper products — this is unusual! Paper napkins, towels, and plates go in the black trash cart
Clean pizza boxes are recyclable; greasy ones go in the black trash cart (not compost)
Only CMA-certified compostable bags (3 gallons or smaller) are accepted in the green cart
Recycling changed from weekly to bi-weekly in January 2025
Use the Be Cart Smart waste directory at denvergov.org to look up any item
Download the Denver Trash and Recycling App for collection schedules and reminders

locations.name: Denver Sustainability Drop-off Events
locations.notes: Denver hosts periodic sustainability drop-off events at rotating locations. Check the Denver Trash and Recycling App or denvergov.org for upcoming dates and locations.

locations.name: Denver CHaRM (Center for Hard-to-Recycle Materials)
locations.notes: Free for Denver residents. Bring proof of Denver residency (utility bill or ID). The CHaRM facility accepts hard-to-recycle items year-round.
